./.title: Team Bob the Developer
./.body:
Team Bob the Developer
Welcome to Team Bob the Developer. If you've found value from the content and would like to work together as instructor partners, this platform provides you with software, hardware, and documents that guide you through working together as a team.
Language
If you are a native speaker in any of the following languages, we are interested in collaborating with you.

Korean
Chinese
Spanish
Japanese
Portuguese
Hindi
Arabic
Russian

Instructor Partnership
Team members prioritize providing great value before generating revenue. Every member takes full ownership of his/her work. Experience, degree, and other factors are not important except the willingness to contribute with unmatchable quality content. Each member receives a high commission rate of 80% from the product with a proven track record.

ABOUT.html.title: About
ABOUT.html.body:
About
Bob the Developer is the brand iOS developers and students recognize and cherish. Tutorials have been translated by multiple languages and shared by major newsletters such as iOS Dev Weekly. Along with conference invites, the blog is ranked 2nd on Medium with 14,000 followers and thousands of daily visitors. The work is distributed via the largest iOS Facebook Page as the admin.
Quality
The Google search results indicate the quality of content based on various factors including visitors, bound rate, and social shares.

Note: As of now, 32 articles have been published.  Most appear on the first page of the search. The result may vary depending on the region and time.

Purpose
The mission of Bob the Developer is to work towards providing affordable and global education. We look for talented individuals who find their fulfillment through contributing, helping, and giving back to the community.

content/course-creation/overview.html.title: Overview
content/course-creation/overview.html.body:
Course Creation Overview
For your effective course creation, we've designed a 6-step process. There are external links and articles available.
Step 1. Research
You have completed the course and read through the GitBook document. You are familiar with the examples and topics.
Step 2. Organization and Preparation
It's time to prepare for your own course material. Many examples use BobClass. Feel free to change it to NickClass, for example. It adds authenticity to your work. For organizing source code and naming guide, please refer to the guide below.

File Organization Guide

Step 3. Documentation
Once you've have your course material ready, it's time to document on GItBook as shown in learnswiftwithbob.com. The document not only serves as a marketing tool, but also as the script for the new Swift version. To learn how to organize files and use GitBook, please visit the links below.

GitBook Document Guide
Effective Example Guide

Step 4. Video Recording
You've got your script(s) and example(s) ready. It's time to teach.

Lecture Guide

Step 5. Video Editing
For introduction and conclusion, the jump cut editing technique is used. It has a couple benefits. You are not required to memorize the entire paragraph and you may void using filter words such as "um" and "like".  
 [Video Editing Guide](/content/course-creation/video-editing-guide.md) -->
Step 6. Course Submission
You may bulk upload lessons on Udemy. If it is your first time creating a course on Udemy, you have to submit a test video. You may find more about the process here.

Udemy Policy Guide

content/course-creation/file-organizatio.title: File Organization Guide
content/course-creation/file-organizatio.body:
File Organization Guide
Source Code Management
Upload files on Dropbox to easily distribute the files on GitBook. Please refer to how the source code is managed in the Learn Swift with Bob Dropbox Folder.
Source Code Naming Guideline
The name is lowercased and connected with _. Remove filer/stop words such as of, the, a, and, for, by. Lesson 4 of Chapter 4  should be

4004_delegate_data_source

Progress Management
You are encouraged to use a spreadsheet to track your progress and organize source code and external links. Please take a look at how Learn Swift with Bob is organized here.

content/course-creation/gitbook-document.title: GitBook Document Guide
content/course-creation/gitbook-document.body:
GitBook Document Guide
GitBook allows you to generate a website using Markdown and Terminal with simple instructions. You may refer to the official  tutorial.
URL Guide for Documenting
The name of the sub-folder should be organic for search engine optimization. The URL should be readable and words are connected with - is rather than _

intermediate-swift/delegate-data-source (o)
2000_intermediate_swift/2004_delegate_data_source (x)

Tips for Translation
You are encouraged to download the script on Github and translate while the table of content and images are in placed. You might have to change the source code links, title for images, and examples.
Text Editor
For lecture notes, the Atom text editor is favored. But, you may choose your favored text editor.
 Document with Atom

Note: For your productivity, feel free to use the Atom shortcuts

content/course-creation/effective-exampl.title: Effective Example Guide
content/course-creation/effective-exampl.body:
Effective Example Guide
A lot of answers from Stack Overflow are rather boring and not engaging.
Personality
Avoid using foo and boo.  It's important to grab their attention first before teaching.
class Foo {
  var a: Boo?
}

Examples should be more fun and familiar. The example below is encouraged.
class MacBook {
  var battery: Status?
}

Visualization
For student engagement and understanding, visualization is encouraged.The image below is extracted from Learn Swift with Bob: Recursive Enums
 An example diagram made with Sketch
There is a Sketch file on Dropbox. You may copy and simply change the name from BobClass to NickClass for your courses.
Practicality
When you first introduce the concept, you don't have to make it practical. However, by the end, there should be one or more practical example that the students might find useful for their own projects.

content/course-creation/video-editing-gu.title: Video Editing Guide
content/course-creation/video-editing-gu.body:
Video Editing Guide
Introduction
There are two choices. Either you may record one sentence at a time and connect them through each sentence. The second is to speak at once. But it requires you to memorize the script longer and you might have to waste time.
You may use Premier Pro or iMovie (free) to edit videos. Bob the Developer videos are all produced with Premier Pro.
Others
You need to use the opening statement, Bob the Developer after introduction for branding and more.
You need to start off with a song
Introduction
Animation Transition
Lecture
Conclusion
